TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi sealed beforefieldinit VerificationAttribute extends System.Attribute
Public NotInheritable Class VerificationAttribute Inherits Attribute
public ref class VerificationAttribute sealed : Attribute

Docs.summary: Defines the metadata attribute of a Web content accessibility rule. This class cannot be inherited.

remarks.format:
## Remarks An instance of the <xref:System.Web.UI.VerificationAttribute> class defines a Web content accessibility rule that can be verified. For more information on Web Content Accessibility Guidelines, see the [World Wide Web Consortium (W3C) Web site](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?linkid=37125).
The minimal amount of information required to define an instance of a <xref:System.Web.UI.VerificationAttribute> includes:
- A guideline that the verification rule represents. The value specified in the constructor sets the <xref:System.Web.UI.VerificationAttribute.Guideline%2A> property.
- A checkpoint of the guideline. The value specified in the constructor sets the <xref:System.Web.UI.VerificationAttribute.Checkpoint%2A> property.
- A checkpoint priority. The value specified in the constructor sets the <xref:System.Web.UI.VerificationAttribute.Priority%2A> property.
- A <xref:System.Web.UI.VerificationReportLevel> enumeration value that represents the reporting level that should be rule belongs to. The value specified in the constructor sets the <xref:System.Web.UI.VerificationAttribute.VerificationReportLevel%2A> property.
- A message that is reported when the verification rule is true. The value specified in the constructor sets the <xref:System.Web.UI.VerificationAttribute.Message%2A> property.
Optional properties of the verification rule that can be specified when creating an instance:
- A <xref:System.Web.UI.VerificationRule> enumeration value that represents how the verification rule should be interpreted. The value specified in the constructor sets the <xref:System.Web.UI.VerificationAttribute.VerificationRule%2A> property.
- A <xref:System.Web.UI.VerificationConditionalOperator> enumeration value that represents the operator in the conditional expression used to test the verification rule. The value specified in the constructor sets the <xref:System.Web.UI.VerificationAttribute.VerificationConditionalOperator%2A> property.
- An accessibility reference guideline URL. The value specified in the constructor sets the <xref:System.Web.UI.VerificationAttribute.GuidelineUrl%2A> property.
- A conditional value representing the right side of a conditional expression. The value specified in the constructor sets the <xref:System.Web.UI.VerificationAttribute.ConditionalValue%2A> property.
- A conditional property representing the left side of a conditional expression. The value specified in the constructor sets the <xref:System.Web.UI.VerificationAttribute.ConditionalProperty%2A> property.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.VerificationAttribute> metadata can be defined class, property, and indexer declarations.
For more information about using attributes, see [Attributes](~/docs/standard/attributes/index.md).
## Examples The following code example demonstrates using the <xref:System.Web.UI.VerificationAttribute> class. In the verification metadata definition, the guidelines used are "WCAG," the Web Content Accessibility Guideline, and "ADA," Americans with Disabilities Act Guidelines. For more information, see the [World Wide Web Consortium (W3C) Web site](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?linkid=37125).
The checkpoints used are "1.1" and "1194.22(a)" for WCAG and ADA, respectively, checkpoints for ensuring that a text equivalent exists for non-text elements. The <xref:System.Web.UI.VerificationAttribute> is applied to the `ImageText` property that represents the text equivalent of another property called `ImageProperty`. If the `ImageText` property is not set, the accessibility verification will return the message "The image is missing a text equivalent."
[!code-csharp[System.Web.UI.VerificationAttribute#1](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_WebNet/System.Web.UI.VerificationAttribute/cs/VerificationAttributeExample.cs#1)] [!code-vb[System.Web.UI.VerificationAttribute#1](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_WebNet/System.Web.UI.VerificationAttribute/vb/VerificationAttributeExample.vb#1)]

remarks.format:
## Remarks The <xref:System.Web.UI.VerificationAttribute.%23ctor%2A> constructor of the <xref:System.Web.UI.VerificationAttribute> class specifies the minimal amount of information needed to define a verification rule. The following default values for the <xref:System.Web.UI.VerificationAttribute> instance are assumed:
- The <xref:System.Web.UI.VerificationAttribute.VerificationRule%2A> property is set as <xref:System.Web.UI.VerificationRule.Required>.
- The <xref:System.Web.UI.VerificationAttribute.VerificationConditionalOperator%2A> property is set as <xref:System.Web.UI.VerificationConditionalOperator.Equals>.
- The <xref:System.Web.UI.VerificationAttribute.GuidelineUrl%2A> property is set as an empty string ("").
- The <xref:System.Web.UI.VerificationAttribute.ConditionalValue%2A> property is set as an empty string ("").
- The <xref:System.Web.UI.VerificationAttribute.ConditionalProperty%2A> property is set as an empty string ("").
- To specify values of the properties in the preceding list beyond their default values, use the <xref:System.Web.UI.VerificationAttribute.%23ctor%2A> or <xref:System.Web.UI.VerificationAttribute.%23ctor%2A> constructor overloads.

MemberSignature.Value: public VerificationAttribute (string guideline, string checkpoint, System.Web.UI.VerificationReportLevel reportLevel, int priority, string message, System.Web.UI.VerificationRule rule, string conditionalProperty);

Docs.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class with accessibility guideline, checkpoint, reporting level, checkpoint priority, error message, .value, and related conditional property.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The `conditionalProperty` parameter is another property that is used as part of the conditional expression to evaluate the verification rule. For example, if the rule parameter is <xref:System.Web.UI.VerificationRule.NotEmptyString> then the related property specified by `conditionalProperty` must not be an empty string ("").
The following default values for the <xref:System.Web.UI.VerificationAttribute> instance are assumed:
- The <xref:System.Web.UI.VerificationAttribute.VerificationConditionalOperator%2A> property is set as <xref:System.Web.UI.VerificationConditionalOperator.Equals>.
- The <xref:System.Web.UI.VerificationAttribute.GuidelineUrl%2A> property is set as an empty string ("").
- The <xref:System.Web.UI.VerificationAttribute.ConditionalProperty%2A> property is set as an empty string ("").
To specify values of the properties in the preceding list beyond their default values, use the <xref:System.Web.UI.VerificationAttribute.%23ctor%2A> constructor overload.

Docs.summary: Gets the accessibility checkpoint reference in the specified property.
Docs.value: A string representing the checkpoint reference.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The <xref:System.Web.UI.VerificationAttribute.Checkpoint%2A> property is set when the <xref:System.Web.UI.VerificationAttribute> instance is created and is required.
For the Web Content Accessibility Guidelines defined on the [World Wide Web Consortium (W3C) Web site](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?linkid=37125) the <xref:System.Web.UI.VerificationAttribute.Checkpoint%2A> property is specified as a guideline number followed by a period (.) followed by a checkpoint number.

member this.ConditionalProperty : string

Attribute.AttributeName: get: System.Runtime.TargetedPatchingOptOut("Performance critical to inline this type of method across NGen image boundaries")

Docs.summary: Gets the left side of a conditional expression used as part of the verification accessibility checkpoint.
Docs.value: The left side of the conditional expression. The default value is an empty string ("").

remarks.format:
## Remarks The <xref:System.Web.UI.VerificationAttribute.ConditionalProperty%2A> property can be set when the <xref:System.Web.UI.VerificationAttribute> instance is created, but is optional. If you use a constructor that does not take a `conditionalProperty` parameter, the default value of an empty string ("") is used.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.VerificationAttribute.ConditionalValue%2A> property is the right side, or value, of a conditional expression that is use in the verification of the accessibility checkpoint. The left side of the conditional expression is specified with the <xref:System.Web.UI.VerificationAttribute.ConditionalProperty%2A>.

The left side of the conditional expression is specified with the <xref:System.Web.UI.VerificationAttribute.ConditionalProperty%2A>.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The <xref:System.Web.UI.VerificationAttribute.Guideline%2A> property is set when the <xref:System.Web.UI.VerificationAttribute> instance is created and is required.
Examples of guidelines include "WCAG 1.1" and "ADA508".

Docs.value: The default value is an empty string ("").

remarks.format:
## Remarks The <xref:System.Web.UI.VerificationAttribute.GuidelineUrl%2A> property can be set when the <xref:System.Web.UI.VerificationAttribute> instance is created, but is optional. If you use a constructor that does not take a `guidelineUrl` parameter, the default value of an empty string ("") is used.
The string entered for the <xref:System.Web.UI.VerificationAttribute.GuidelineUrl%2A> property is not checked for correctness.

remarks.format: ## Remarks The <xref:System.Web.UI.VerificationAttribute.Priority%2A> property defines the <xref:System.Web.UI.VerificationAttribute.Checkpoint%2A> property's impact on accessibility. Both the <xref:System.Web.UI.VerificationAttribute.Checkpoint%2A> and <xref:System.Web.UI.VerificationAttribute.Priority%2A> property are set when the <xref:System.Web.UI.VerificationAttribute> instance is created and is required.

remarks.format: ## Remarks The <xref:System.Web.UI.VerificationAttribute.VerificationRule%2A> property can be set when the <xref:System.Web.UI.VerificationAttribute> instance is created, but is optional. If you use a constructor that does not take a `rule` parameter, the default value of <xref:System.Web.UI.VerificationRule.Required> is used.
